intro: Salix calcicola var. calcicola, commonly known as the limestone willow, is a shrub native to arid and semi-arid regions of the southwestern United States. It is adapted to grow in calcium-rich soils, often found in rocky or gravelly habitats. The plant has slender, branching stems and small, narrow leaves that are typically covered in a fine, white pubescence. It produces catkins in early spring, which are its primary means of seed dispersal. This species is notable for its ecological role in stabilizing soil in harsh environments.
